Authorities: Image shows suspect at scene of second Marathon bombing

No arrests made yet in attacks

An official briefed on the Marathon bombing investigation said that authorities have an image of a suspect carrying a black bag on Boylston Street. (7:46 p.m.)
  • Bomb scare at courthouse
  • Hospital clears out after scare

Dozens of bomb blast patients leave hospitals

Officials at three Boston hospitals said they expect all of their patients from Monday's bombings to survive. (7:48 p.m.)
  • Bruins, Garden honor victims

List of victims

The confirmed victims of the Marathon explosion. We will continue to update this list.

Obama to join prayer service for victims

The president and Michelle Obama will attend the service at 11 a.m. Thursday. (6:39 p.m.)

Disgust over Marathon medals sold on eBay

People are selling medals for this year's Boston Marathon online for hundreds of dollars. (2:03 p.m.)

Pictures

Victims remembered, answers sought

Bruins captain Zdeno Chara acknowledged a "Believe in Boston" sign before tonight's game at TD Garden. Jim Davis/Globe Staff
At the marathon starting line in Hopkinton, a touching banner was hung in tribute to the bombing victims. Billy Baker/Globe Staff
A US marshal walked outside during a bomb threat at the John Joseph Moakley United States Courthouse in Boston. Jessica Rinaldi/Reuters
A crowd of journalists and people who were evacuated from the court stood in a parking lot during the bomb threat. Jessica Rinaldi/Reuters
An investigator carried an evidence bag off a roof top near the site of two explosions at the finish line of the Boston Marathon. Brian Snyder/Reuters
Flowers and a Boston University key chain at a makeshift memorial for student 23-year-old Lu Lingzi from China. Stan Honda / AFP / Getty Images
A sign hangs on a barricade to Boylston Street at Berkeley Street. Bill Greene / Globe Staff
With the US Capitol in the background, American flags waved at half-staff at the Washington Monument. AP Photo
FBI crime scene investigators stood near an evidence marker on Boylston Street just past Berkeley Street. Darren McCollester / Getty Images
Patty Campbell, mother of Krystle Campbell, who died in the bombing, spoke from her front porch. Bill Greene / Globe Staff
The remains of a black backpack that the FBI said contained one of the bombs that exploded during the Boston Marathon. FBI Photo
The remains of a pressure cooker that the FBI said was part of one of the bombs that exploded during the Boston Marathon. AP Photo/FBI
Brandi Brooks, 17, and her sister, Cheyanne, 3, looked at a memorial to 8-year old Martin Richard in Dorchester. AP Photo

    Ricin indicated in mail to Obama, senator

    In a capital city on edge, letters sent to President Barack Obama and a Mississippi senator tested positive for poisonous ricin in preliminary checks. (4:31 p.m.)

    Senate rejects expanded gun checks

    The Senate has rejected a bipartisan effort to expand federal background checks to more firearms buyers in a crucial showdown over gun control. (4:34 p.m.)

    Tierney tops delegation in Q1 fundraising

    Among House members, US Rep. John Tierney leads the Massachusetts delegation in amount of dollars raised during the first quarter of the year. (2:35 p.m.)

    Worcester store clerk shot in face

    The shooting of a Honey Farms store clerk was part of a violent seven-hour span in the city. (1:12 p.m.)

    Girl, 3, found unresponsive in pond

    A young Wareham girl who wandered away from home is in critical condition after being found floating unconscious in Dick’s Pond, police said. (11:03 a.m.)
